subject: Re: [junit] Non Plus Ultra Coverage Measure?
msgSnippet: A problem with your terms. A coverage measure is a measure -- it does not cover anything. There are different kinds of test coverage, measured by the aspects
messageBody:
A problem with your terms. A "coverage measure" is a measure -- it does not cover anything.

There are different kinds of test coverage, measured by the aspects of the program they cover. 100% line coverage seems to be the most definite of the ones you list, although it does not take into account different data sets. It is possible to have 100% line coverage and still have a defect because you have not written code to handle a particular case.

I do not like test coverage measurement. It is not smart enough. Obviously, 90% coverage is much better than 50% coverage, but the return on investment goes down considerably up over 90%. My opinion.

Take care.

>So said javainsel on 2003-05-04 --------------------
>I read about Line Coverage, Branch Coverage, Condition Coverage,
>Path Coverage, Call Coverage, Loop Coverage, Linear Code Sequence
>and Jump (LCAJ) Coverage and Data Flow Coverage. And also I read
>something about Data Chains (same as Data Flow?).
>
>Is there a coverage measure which covers 100%?
>
>And is there a ranking of coverage measures in terms of how much
>they cover compared to the other measures?
>
>
